summary: Email chain between prosecutors and defense counsel regarding discovery issues in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The defense raises multiple technical and procedural problems with document production, including missing files, metadata gaps, and requests for unredacted FBI reports and grand jury subpoenas.

persons.name: Annie Phifer
persons.context: Mentioned as a recipient in an email regarding discovery requests, indicating involvement in the document production process for the Maxwell case.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as 'Ms. Maxwell', the defendant whose defense team is requesting discovery materials. The emails discuss providing her with discovery at the MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).

connections.description: Phifer is involved in the document production process for the government, which is opposing Maxwell's defense team.

events.title: Discovery Production Completion
events.description: Email indicates completion of discovery request number 6 for the defense, with materials to be sent via FTP.

events.title: Discovery Production
events.description: Government agreed to create a new hard drive containing the entire discovery production for Maxwell's defense.

events.title: FBI Report
events.description: Defense requests an unredacted version of an FBI report dated December 6, 2006, bearing Bates number SDNY_GM_02050812-14.

keyFacts: Defense counsel raises multiple discovery issues, including missing documents, metadata gaps in PROD011 and PROD015, and requests for unredacted FBI reports and grand jury subpoenas.
The defense notes that a CD produced on November 18, 2020, did not work on the prison computer at the MDC, and Maxwell's laptop lacks a CD drive, hindering her ability to review materials.

An article in the Daily Beast referenced a search warrant affidavit for a cell-site simulator used to track Maxwell's cellphone before her arrest, prompting the defense to inquire if the government unsealed this or other materials.
